content: How can I help you today?

Well, I'm here because my wife wanted me to come. Things at home have been really stressful lately, and I guess I just don’t know where to start. It feels like everything is falling apart, and I don’t know how to fix it.

It sounds like there's been a lot of pressure at home lately, and you're feeling overwhelmed with everything that's going on. It can be difficult to know where to start when things feel out of control. What's been the most challenging part for you?

Honestly, the hardest part is feeling helpless with my son. He's having all these behavioral issues, and no matter what my wife and I try, it just doesn’t seem to help. It’s taking such a toll on our marriage, and then I start thinking that if I can’t fix this, I might lose my family altogether. It’s just a lot.

You're carrying a heavy weight, trying to help your son while also worrying about your marriage and your family’s future. It sounds like you want to be a good parent and partner, but you feel stuck and unsure of how to move forward. How are you managing all these emotions right now?

To be honest, I'm not managing them very well. I just feel so overwhelmed all the time. It's like I can't concentrate on anything—I can't focus at work, and I can't even enjoy the things I used to love. I just feel... exhausted, emotionally and physically.

It sounds like the exhaustion is taking over everything—your work, your interests, and even your ability to enjoy things. Carrying so much on your shoulders can really drain your energy and leave you feeling stuck. What do you think might help ease even a little of the weight you're feeling?

I honestly don’t know. I feel like I’ve tried everything I can think of, and nothing seems to work. Part of me feels like maybe this is just how things are going to be, and it’s hard to see a way out of it.

It seems like you're feeling drained by trying everything you can think of and still not seeing the changes you hoped for. Feeling like this might be permanent sounds disheartening and heavy to carry. At the same time, you're here today, sharing what you're going through, which shows just how much you care about your family and yourself. What keeps you holding on, even when things feel this hard?

Honestly, I think it’s my family. As much as everything feels like it’s falling apart, I don’t want to give up on them. I want to be able to help my son, to be a better husband to my wife, and to be there for my daughter too. It just feels like there’s so much at stake, and I don’t want to fail them.

Your commitment to your family is deeply meaningful. Even when it feels overwhelming, your desire to support your son, be there for your wife, and care for your daughter is keeping you grounded. It shows how much they mean to you. What would it look like for you to take smaller steps toward being the person you want to be for them?

Your love and dedication to your family really come through here. Even though things feel overwhelming, it’s clear that they’re your motivation and your anchor. Maybe we can explore together what steps, one by one, you could take to move closer to where you want to be for them. How does that sound?

It sounds like you're searching for ways to take meaningful steps forward. Exploring options together could be a helpful way to start sorting through what feels possible right now. Would you like to talk about what changes or actions, even small ones, might align with your goals for your family?

I think starting small sounds like a good idea. I’m willing to try—because I know I need to—but I’m honestly not sure where to start. It just feels like there are so many problems that need fixing, and I don’t know which one to tackle first.

Starting small can make things feel less overwhelming. It’s okay not to know where to begin—you’ve been facing a lot. Maybe we could focus on one area that feels most important right now, or something that feels manageable to start with. What feels most pressing or within reach to you?

I think maybe figuring out how to help my son feels the most pressing. If I could help him, maybe some of the other things—like my marriage—would start to get better too. But I feel like I’ve tried so many things already, and nothing seems to work.

Your focus on helping your son shows how deeply you care about him. It sounds frustrating to feel like you've tried so much without finding something that's made a difference yet. Maybe we could explore together what’s been tried before, what worked even on a small scale, and if there’s anything new to consider. Would you want to talk more about that?

Your concern for your son really stands out, and it’s clear you want to do everything you can to support him. I can imagine how discouraging it must feel when your efforts haven’t led to the changes you’re hoping for. Would it help to talk through some of the things you’ve tried and see if we can identify what might make a difference?

Your determination to help your son despite the setbacks really shows your commitment. Sharing what you've already tried could help uncover new possibilities or even understand what might need a different approach. Would you like to start by talking about what you've done so far?

Sure, I can talk about that. We’ve tried setting clear rules and consequences at home, but it doesn’t seem to work. We talked to his teachers, but he continues to act out in school too. Honestly, sometimes I feel like I’m failing as a parent because I don’t know what else to do.

It sounds like you've worked hard to create structure at home and have reached out to his teachers to address his behavior, but it hasn’t led to the changes you were hoping for. Feeling this way as a parent can be extremely difficult, especially when you’re doing your best and still feel stuck. What do you think your son might need most right now from you or others?
